page.title: 12Abbots Park,Cornwood(1)
page.content: Abbots Park,situated opposite the church and so named because long ago it formed part of an abbot's property, was a rough pasture,grazed by cows from a nearby farm.Among its grasses one could find 8 or more species of butterfly,including the common blue and the holly blue.Large flocks of swallows and martins swooped over the grass,and during the migrating season black redstarts passed through.The high-pitched scream of swifts could be heard above the chorus of bird-song and at dusk the even higher-pitched squeaking of bats was a common sound. By Christmas 1973 the builders had moved in and the first house of a new estate had been completed.The area was a sea of mud and its wildlife was in retreat.
